Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Situation2: They handle a busy checkout with a long queue during peak hours.
Story:
I stand behind the register, scanning groceries as quickly as I can. The line stretches past the candy racks, and customers shift impatiently, glancing at their watches. My mind keeps drifting to the email draft open on my phone in the break room. My mentor asked me to reach out if I had any questions, no matter how small. There’s a term in the training manual I don’t quite understand. It’s not stopping my work, but I know she expects me to communicate openly. 

But right now, every beep of the scanner feels like a countdown. The store manager expects me to keep the line moving, double-check prices, and handle cash without mistakes. If I pause to send a message, even for a minute, the line will grow, and customers will get frustrated. My mentor’s words echo in my head—“Don’t hesitate to ask questions”—but so does my manager’s warning about keeping the checkout efficient. I grip the register tighter, feeling the pressure from both sides, unsure which expectation to meet first.
